title: Here's What We Know About The Alleged Fort Lauderdale Airport Shooter
text:
The suspected shooter who opened fire Friday at Fort Lauderdale International Airport, killing at least five, was identified by a US senator and other media outlets as Esteban Santiago. Eight other people were injured after the gunman opened fire close to 1 p.m. at the airport, officials said.
Sen. Bill Nelson of Florida cited a military ID that was found on the gunman during his arrest. But it was not immediately confirmed if the ID card belonged to the suspect, and authorities did not immediately release his identity.
However, multiple media outlets, citing family members and law enforcement sources, confirmed Santiago’s identity. They also reported that he was based in Alaska as part of the National Guard.
ID: 10280699 #CNN: Picture of alleged FLL shooter obtained by CNN
— AnneClaire Stapleton (@AnneClaireCNN) ID: 10281764 Broward County Commissioner Chip LaMarca said on Facebook that the shooter was a passenger on a Canadian flight with a checked gun.
“He claimed his bag and took the gun from baggage and went into the bathroom to load it,” LaMarca wrote. “Came out shooting people in baggage claim.”
Air Canada tweeted that no one by Santiago’s name, nor were there any checked guns, listed on any flight to the city. Canada’s government also issued a statement insisting the suspect was never on a flight from Canada. There reports that the flight originated in Alaska and may have stopped over in Minnesota.
CBS News, meanwhile, aired footage of what was purported to be the shooter’s 9mm gun on the ground.
ID: 10281575 NEW: Image of firearm believed to be used by Ft. Lauderdale Int'l Airport shooter, ID'd as Esteban Santiago… https://t.co/Yqj1g2JRUe
— CBS News (@CBSNews) ID: 10281231 Little more information about the suspected shooter was immediately released publicly as authorities continued to work to secure the airport except that he was unharmed and being interview by investigators.
A man matching Santiago’s information was charged with damaging property worth more than $50 in Anchorage and verbal assault in January 2016. Both of the misdemeanors were dismissed by prosecutors in March, but according to court records, the case remains open.
He was also has two traffic violations, one for an issue with his taillight and another for not carrying his insurance in April 2015, according to court records reviewed by BuzzFeed News.

Wilfredo Lee / AP People take cover outside Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport, Jan. 6, 2017.
ID: 10281828 ABC News and other outlets, citing unnamed law enforcement officials, reported that Santiago had been treated for mental illness, possibly post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) after making contact with the FBI.
The motive for the attack was also not immediately known.
“It sounds like that he is a mental case,” Nelson said on CNN. “Thank goodness it’s not a terrorist-inspired case, but we won’t know until they” complete their investigation.
ID: 10281827 N.J. aunt of Ft. Lauderdale airport shooting suspect: 'He lost his mind' in Iraq https://t.co/59NYY9ndLa
— NJ.com (@njdotcom) ID: 10281883 Santiago’s aunt, Maria Ruiz Rivera, of Union City in New Jersey, told NJ.com that the 26-year-old was sent to Iraq after joining the National Guard, and upon his return, was hospitalized for mental health problems.
“He lost his mind,” Ruiz Rivera said in Spanish.
After a trip to Puerto Rico to visit his father, who eventually, died, he settled in Alaska, where he fathered a daughter in September, she told NJ.com. During her last contact with her nephew, he seemed fine, she added.
